awd_titl_txt: Manipulating light-matter interactions in bulk anisotropic metamaterials
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical description: Light interacts with matter in many different ways that can be observed in our everyday life. This includes scattering, reflection, refraction, absorption or excitation of chemical processes in, for example, retinal rods and cones of the human eye. The likelihood and strength of a particular light-matter interaction is governed by so-called selection rules. Many light-matter interaction processes are forbidden, or more precisely, highly-improbable, therefore limiting fundamental studies and applications of optical materials and processes. The ability to manipulate these improbable interactions is likely to enhance fundamental knowledge in many fields, including atomic, molecular and optical physics, photonics, chemistry, and nanotechnology. This research focuses on developing new nanostructured optical materials and structures, termed metamaterials, that help create specially shaped light beams. These custom-made light beams enable accessing those previously forbidden light-matter interactions. Beyond its fundamental science significance, this research could enable applications in spectroscopy and sensing devices, photovoltaic systems and quantum computing devices. This hands-on experience, along with exposure to state-of-the-art scientific problems and their investigations, helps thoroughly prepare participating students for future science and engineering careers. 

Technical description: Spectroscopic transitions in atoms and molecules that are not allowed within the electric-dipole approximation, but occur due to higher-order terms in the interaction between matter and radiation, are called dipole-forbidden. Dipole-forbidden optical transitions in atoms form the basis of next-generation atomic clocks, and of high-fidelity qubits used in quantum information processors and quantum simulators. However, dipole-forbidden transitions are very weak and therefore exhibit narrow natural linewidths.  Recently, it was realized that orbital angular momentum, or vortex beams can make symmetry-forbidden transitions possible in atoms, molecules, and artificial atoms or nanocrystals. However, the transition rate depends on the beam size and increases when the vortex beam size decreases. The goal of the proposed research is to investigate and demonstrate the possibility of probing forbidden transitions in artificial atoms using orbital angular momentum carrying beams that have been demagnified to subwavelength scales using strongly anisotropic metamaterial structures. Interactions of orbital angular momentum beams with atoms enable hollow-beam traps, improve the spatial resolution of stimulated emission depletion microscopy and facilitate quantum information processing. Graduate and undergraduate students involved in this project gain hands-on experience in spectroscopy, nanofabrication and optical characterization of novel nanostructured materials.

por.por_cntn:
The discovery of an orbital angular momentum (OAM) of light opened a new branch of optical physics that has facilitated studies of such phenomena as rotary photon drag, angular uncertainty relationships, rotational frequency shifts, and spin-orbital coupling. The OAM beams have been proposed and employed in many applications such as high dimensional quantum information, quantum cryptography, and quantum memories. Also, OAM-carrying beams of electrons, neutrons, and electromagnetic terahertz radiation have been demonstrated.

In this project we focused on the following specific aspect of the OAM beam interaction with matter – interaction of structured light beams with matter drastically changes when the size of the optical beam is comparable to the size of the resonant optical nanostructure.

On the macro scale, structured light can be easily generated and manipulated. However, modern applications of structured light for subwavelength imaging, high capacity communication systems, and micromanipulation motivated the development of ultra-compact, microscale sources of structured light. However, when it comes to the interactions of light-matter at quantum level, for example, the probing of atomic forbidden (or dark) states and building multi-dimensional quantum encryption systems, the scale of the beam has to be reduced even further down to the nanoscale in order to be comparable to the size of quantum dots or even atoms

Therefore, first, we investigated the new physics of light-matter interaction when the size of the structured light beam is comparable to the electron wavefunctions in matter. In this case, long-wavelength approximation is not valid and the full integral of the coupling Hamiltonian is required to describe the structured light matter interaction.

In order to address this problem, we investigated the following optical systems:

  1. The emergence of optical metamaterials opens new opportunities for spatial pattern compression from the micro- to nano-scale. By exploiting strongly anisotropic optical properties of engineered nanostructures, we design and demonstrate de-magnifying hyperbolic metamaterial-based structures that reduce the size of an OAM beam below the diffraction limit.
  2. Rydberg excitons in the Cu2O that are single quantum objects of up to micrometer size, allowing to study light-matter interactions with focused OAM beam. Rydberg excitons have been chosen because the wave-function diameter can be matched with the focal spot size of the OAM beam because the radius for exciton wavefunction increases with the primary quantum number.
  3. OAM beam interactions with all-dielectric silicon meta-atoms supporting unique optically induced electric and magnetic geometry-driven resonances. We found that light-matter interactions of structured light beams with dielectric particles of various shapes and orientations lead to new insights and applications of structured light and optical nanostructures. In particular, our study may enable novel approaches for remote sensing or imaging in scattering media, such as fog, clouds, dust, or aerosols, as well as well as for new detection schemes, sensitive to the gradient of electric field or the magnetic field, and thus, facilitating new ways of characterization of quantum properties of spatially-dependent optical fields.

Second, by harnessing the properties of total momentum conservation, spin-orbit interaction, and optical non-Hermitian symmetry breaking, we demonstrate an OAM-tunable vortex microlaser, providing chiral light states of variable topological charges at a single telecommunication wavelength. The scheme of the non–Hermitian-controlled chiral light emission at room temperature can be further scaled up for simultaneous multi-vortex emissions in a flexible manner. Our work provides a route for the development of the next generation of multidimensional OAM-spin-wavelength division multiplexing technology.

Third, we exploited OAM illumination to excite and control high-order multipole resonances, inaccessible by plane wave or Gaussian illumination. We showed that one can control the amplitude and spectral position of a magnetic quadrupole resonance by changing particle geometry and/or illumination angle. It is noteworthy that the results presented here can be extended to a Hermite–Gaussian illumination, which also posses the asymmetrical phase distribution for some modes. The results obtained can find applications for remote sensing, spectroscopy, reconstruction, of the parameters of the highly scattering media, and OAM beam detection, paving the way for new applications for structured light.
